citations.narrative:
During the inspection the licensee reported an incident where a park guest was bitten by a camel. Further investigation
showed that on August 4, 2024, no facility representative was present when a visitor was hand feeding a camel at the
enclosure in the drive thru area of the park. The park visitor was bitten or scratched on the left index finger during this
feeding. The park guest did not report this incident to facility personnel but later reported this injury to the State
Department of Health which then placed the camel on a thirty day quarantine. This incident resulted in a negative health
impact to the park guest. Failure to adequately monitor public contact with animals poses a risk of injury to both the
animals and the public. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at
all times during periods of public contact. To be corrected by August 16.

There was a smell of decaying flesh and rancid odor near an enclosure housing two alpine wolves. Numerous pieces of
rotting chicken could be seen on the ground and scattered over a large area inside the enclosure. Decaying and rotting
meat does not provide appropriate nutrition. It is also a potential attractant for pests and insects and is a source of
contamination to the environment. Animal food should be wholesome, palatable, and free of contamination to maintain all
animals in good health. The licensee must remove rotting food and provide all animals an appropriate diet. Corrected at
the time of inspection on August 13, 2024.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 13-Aug-2024, and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 14-Aug-
2024.This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
During the inspection the licensee reported an incident where a park guest was bitten by a camel. Further investigation 
showed that on August 4, 2024, no facility representative was present when a visitor was hand feeding a camel at the 
enclosure in the drive thru area of the park. The park visitor was bitten or scratched on the left index finger during this 
feeding. The park guest did not report this incident to facility personnel but later reported this injury to the State 
Department of Health which then placed the camel on a thirty day quarantine. This incident resulted in a negative health 
impact to the park guest. Failure to adequately monitor public contact with animals poses a risk of injury to both the 
animals and the public. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at 
all times during periods of public contact. To be corrected by August 16. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
There was a smell of decaying flesh and rancid odor near an enclosure housing two alpine wolves. Numerous pieces of 
rotting chicken could be seen on the ground and scattered over a large area inside the enclosure. Decaying and rotting 
meat does not provide appropriate nutrition. It is also a potential attractant for pests and insects and is a source of 
contamination to the environment. Animal food should be wholesome, palatable, and free of contamination to maintain all 
animals in good health. The licensee must remove rotting food and provide all animals an appropriate diet. Corrected at 
the time of inspection on August 13, 2024. 
 
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 13-Aug-2024, and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 14-Aug-
2024.This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
